commentBody: Sorry to complain but the link to the answer key generates a PDF copy of the blank puzzle instead of the completed form.
Got this one almost immediately, which is most unlike me! So yeah, a little easy for a Thursday, but a lot of fun.

Weird-looking grid, but interesting theme and decent fill. Not bad overall. Still too easy for a Thursday. 

The overall difficulty in the past few weeks has been annoyingly low. 

Sure an easy week every once in a while is fine, the same as with a week whose difficulty is higher then average. But I feel that this low end on the scale has overstayed its welcome.

There hasn't been anything wrong with the puzzles, per se, so I'm not blaming the constructors at all. However, the editing team should be aware of the overall decline in toughness.
This was clever. Once I got box braids it set me on the right path to the down clues. Still stumbled over a few but eventually got it. Loved Mr. T as an answer here!
Solved the theme easily enough, but I felt like I was missing something since the down clues, while valid words/phrases, seemed completely nonsensical. Meh. Not a fan of the theme
The theme was easy but the unrelated words were lazy. Maybe I'm missing something, but it would have been more fun if those words were somehow related to a theme. Or to anything, really.
Need to correct the link to the answer key.
A themeless puzzle with a twist. Fun, quick fill once I got it.
So satisfying when it clicked! A really, really fun one.

Because the unclued (unbraided) down entries are real words, I was imagining they could somehow be mangled to fit the corresponding clue:

“Academic achievements” = DOGBEDS: that’s what the graduates at obedience class are given?

“Doesn’t allow” = FERRIES: undesirables at the island paradise are removed that way?

“Available, as an apartment”=FERMENT: after a bad batch of kimchi, no one would rent it?

Anyone want to try TOERING or BLUEHEN??

A fun one overall! Got through it rather quickly, despite misinterpreting the effect of the braids. I solved the paired verticals first, and there for had some acrosses crossed on occasion. I was happy enough to see valid clues in the braids, without realizing I had it all backwards! If solving with pen and paper, I would have been satisfied that I at least had the intended answers to each clue. In this case, I am glad the app gives the extra push to solve for the intended configuration!

A fun one!
These BOXBRAIDS look good on you, puzzle.
I would have gone wild if you hadn’t added the shading, especially because I’ve never heard of box braids.

A very cute theme that was fun to solve. I can't imagine this puzzle without the shading to hint at what was going on! As it was I almost got hung up around the BIOTA/DORA cross, but it eventually all clicked.
Adam, I just love seeing your name in the byline because I know I'm in for a good time. I was not disappointed. You are a true maven. Very very clever theme!
I run dark mode and the shading did not show. I finally gave up and did Reveal, but all it showed as wrong was ECG. Too "clever" to be fun...

When I completed the NW corner and saw the trick, I was not optimistic!

But this was a very smooth, cool puzzle. 

TRIX are for kids!  But I still don’t know what TLDR means, though I see it often.  I like to get meaning from context but this may require a google.
Tricky.  I got the clues, but braided the wrong words.  Thought the reversed letters was in every second row was part of the theme.
My wife and I always do the puzzle together. We finished this one to extend our streak. But now we may get divorced. Adam Wagner, I hope you're happy.

This was fun. I thought the movie director was Paul Heig and the two in a row were hoes, so I spent some time shuffling the theme answers around (so instead of TOESHOE I had TEOSHOE on the theory that you'd drag the right-hand shades boxes to the left, or something) before I came to read the column. Thankfully the column explained FOES. I was so obsessed with moving those letters around that I didn't notice the downs made real words until after I read the column. Very cool!
This was so good! 👏👏👏
Really enjoyed this one

I saw what was going on pretty quickly, but didn't catch on to how the answers were suppose to be entered, so I initially had all the downs in normally with half of the acrosses mangled. I eventually swapped the pairs of letters, but not before getting slowed down by the first letter of 24A, since I'd never heard of the director and I thought maybe it was directed by the star, whose name shares a couple of letters (and 24D was an obscure enough pun that I wasn't getting it). Tough to flyspeck when some of the words are doing the wiggle-waggle. I eventually resorted to looking up the movie, and came in just a bit over average. I would have gotten it by running the alphabet on that one letter if I'd swapped the braided words first.

I expect some people will be hating on this later on. As always happens.

I'm wondering if anyone else made the mistake that cost me 20 minutes: I figured out the braiding theme fairly quickly, but I entered the answers so that they would be correct in the *down* direction, while containing flipped letters on every other line in the *across* direction (e.g., "OEDS").  The way I explained the trick to myself was "The grid is 'braided,' but if you 'unbraid' these strands, flipping the letters in each of these pairs every time the gray square is on the right, all the acrosses become correct." I thought it was just a cool "extra" that (when you fill it that way) the shaded zig-zags also formed legit English words, albeit kind of random ones. Eventually I realized it must be the opposite way (all the acrosses correct, all the downs confusing), did the unbraiding on the screen rather than in my brain, and got the happy music....but not before spending 20 minutes trying to figure out if I had made a mistake somewhere else.

For sure, the way the constructor intended it is better than the way I filled it, because his way contained a visually correct grid (all the words shown were real, they just didn't match the clues) and mine contained ugliness like "OEDS." Still, Thursdays DO sometimes contain weird things that look at first glance like mistakes, so it didn't seem obvious at first that my way wasn't the intended way. Was it just me??

Wow! When I finished the puzzle, I imagined Adam Wagner poring over his wordlists to find entries that would work. I now have equal parts of disappointment that the theme entries were the product of a Python script and admiration that Mr. Wagner made the effort to learn enough Python to pull this off.

I was surprised to come here and see people calling the puzzle easy. Part of what caused me to struggle was some wrong answers, like APP at 1A instead of PDF. It didn’t help that when you have a word slot selected, the shading is almost invisible. (I don’t much like grids with circles, but that might have worked better.)

It took me 10 minutes or so to realize what was going on with the braiding, though some of that may have been due to the potent margaritas I had with my birthday dinner. 

And when I had the grid filled but got the “Not quite there” message, it took me a bit to notice that the Across answers all made sense. Once I did, it was easy to find my mistake. 

Thanks, Mr. Wagner, for a challenging but ultimately solvable Thursday!

Enjoyed this one. 
I'm in awe of the patience it must have taken to construct a puzzle like this. 
Definitely a shout-out to Adam and the editors for their hard work. It's truly groundbreaking puzzle 

Cheers to everyone: Adam, Christina, Joel and of course Deb who's humor is the glue for solvers to stick with it. This one anyway. Without her commentary I would never have had the confidence to join the Thursday Club. 
Looking forward to Adam's next endeavor.
For me, sorting out the braided answers was the key to solving the hairstyle clue, since I'd never heard of the style, the film or the actor!

This solved a little more slowly for me simply because my eyes have trouble tracking the zig-zag patterns of the braids. But I loved the cleverness of this theme. Well done, Adam!

Extra fun from the pairing of TOE RING and TOE SHOE, two appearances of rabbits in TRIX and ANNIE'S, and the mirror symmetry of BANK SAFE and I'M BATMAN (although those words wouldn't be a declaration by Bruce Wayne, lest he gives away his secret identity, but by the Caped Crusader).
It figures yesterday's puzzle was tgtbt. Now comes one gimmickier than ever. Oh well, back to reading, Alice  Munro aamof,

Jailbreaking actually unlocked many tweaks to improve battery life, not sure why the article states jailbreaking resulted in horrible battery life. Just a truly a random and false thought, never even heard that as a myth before.
Not bad, though as a former resident I can attest that Karl abides in San Francisco, and doesn’t generally visit the Bay Area.

So, is two strands really a braid? Leaving that aside, for those like me who have trouble visualizing things like this, the solved puzzle on xwordinfo.com makes it easier to see what's going on. https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=5/23/2024

Oh what fun that was!! What a clever and twisty puzzle!! And as a newer solver coming up on a year in a few months, I'm still always tickled when I can figure out a Thursday theme all on my own and solve it without any help! Huzzah! 

I also solved it in half the time of my Thursday average. I don't know if that means everyone's going to say it was too easy or if I'm just significantly making improvements on my solving times, but it was really enjoyable either way. 

After some travel out of the country with my MIL, who is experiencing advancing dementia, she is staying with us at our place for a bit. There's so much that we struggle to try to make sense of in what she's going through, which doesn't seem possible. Today was a very bad day for her. I'm so grateful for puzzles like this at the end of a long day that are fun and challenging--but solvable. I'm so grateful for solvable in what often seems increasingly unsolvable circumstances. 

In life, I seek answers that too often just don't exist. I'm not always sure I can find the answers by myself in a crossword puzzle yet, but I know the answers exist....  and if I didn't know it, I can get it on the crosses or learn it some other way. Loving that! 

Thank you to the constructors, editors, amazing column writers, and everyone else involved, who bring fun sanity to an insane world!

🍸Cheers, fellow solvers! 🍸
For some reason I started with the downs so I did it backwards.
Another time waster.  How these overly clever puzzles get in is above my pay grade.  Just gotta do 'em to keep the streak intact.

I know that this would have been possibly too challenging, but I would have loved to see the actual down entries (eg DOGBED) be connected to the theme/clues in some way, other than being random words. 
I think it would have added a whole new layer to an already fun fill.

Wow, one of my least favorite puzzles in years. Any “trick” you can just ignore by solving across seems kind of lacking. As does using Python — why not ask Chat GPT?

Plus hanging the entire thing on an obscure Janet Jackson movie (yes I saw it) seems like a reach, esp. when box braids aren’t even part of the constructors culture.

I feel like I’m back at the challah factory from Sunday’s grid. Adored this puzzle, from the theme (which I figured out pretty much immediately) to the clues. “Two in a row” was my favorite bit of wordplay from the day (and possibly the week), but I also enjoyed the surprise but welcome appearance from Batman,

Dear Editor,

Yet another case of the creator and/or clue writer(s) trying harder to impress themselves instead of trying to impress the puzzle’s solver.  

While it’s interesting that the two braided words end up making other unbraided words, the unbraided words had nothing to do with the clues.  

So it’s more gimmick than puzzle, and every time you publish a gimmick you’re actually eroding the NYT Crossword brand.  

Again, just because it can be done, doesn’t mean it should be done. 

@Senior Editors, are you paying attention to what’s going on here?
That was a slog. Sadly, my dogged determination made me see it through to the end. I think I need to get a life.

Loved the tricky hidden trick, although I got it sideways and kept the downs straight and zigged the acrosses.  
Still worked - just didn't solve!  
Clue of the day: Karl the Fog!

i thought this was an easy Thursday, like Tuesday-Wednesday level clues with a monkey wrench of a gimmick thrown into it. Appreciated how the downs can be ready normally or zig-zaggy, but also resonated with the complains from others in the comments thread

The constructor clearly has a twisted mind, and I love it! 

Like others, I was initially fooled into thinking the across answers were scrambled, but then I untangled my thoughts and realized it was a vertical trick. BRAIDS then came quickly but it took a while to get BOX. 

Excellent clue for DIMES (Tiniest change) and RISK (Dangerous thing to assume). 

Thanks Adam, this was great fun!

At first I was lost in this puzzle, I just didn't get the theme. Why is MR T backwards? My acrosses don't make sense, is it part of the theme? Agggh!

I put it aside for a while, and when I came back all the confusion started to unravel, and I understood where the "braid" part fit in ("hairstyle" was the only part of the revealer that helped me get BOXBRAIDS)

Pretty clever, and tricksy! (though TRIX are for kids)

Very elegant! I loved the braiding concept and especially appreciated that the unbraided downs made real words . "Two in a row?" for FOES was my favorite clue/answer pairing. "This is the life!" For BIOTA was a close second. I didn't have a whole lot on the first pass, and looking back, I don't know why. Until I picked up on the trick, I was getting a little nervous, but then things moved along fairly quickly. Lora instead of ARLO at 43A and help US instead of SAVE US at 46A slowed me down in the SE, but it all got sorted out. PSA: With rabbits appearing twice in the clues, it's a good time to remind everyone to check for nests in your lawn before you mow. https://www.greenwoodwildlife.org/check-your-yard-for-rabbit-nests-before-mowing/

A bit of a hairy solve,


but in the end,


it weaves me spellbound.

Wow! and... whew. Really enjoyed this one. Tumbled to the trick fairly early, but with my poor memory still had to stop and ponder to remember exactly how it worked at each theme section. Still managed to come in below my Thursday average.

And... thought it was jaw-dropping that each of the down theme answers without the swerve were also legitimate terms - DOGBEDS, FERRIES, etc. 

Only answer history search today was more about the clue, and... yes - TRIX was clued exactly once as:
"____are for kids." 

And... puzzle find today was also inspired by TRIX. A Thursday puzzle from February 20, 2003. Theme answers in that one:

CHEXOUTOFREHAB
KIXITUPANOTCH
TRIXOFTHETRADE

I'm done. 

..

Well, this was a capital-P Puzzle for me.  I was flummoxed for what felt like a very long time, because I entered the theme’s down answers as downs rather than being braided, which led to all kinds of theories as to what was going on, and many a “Huh?” and “Wha?”, and much gerrymandering among the across answers

Underneath, there was faith that things would eventually become clear.  And they did.  But this was as long of an “I don’t get it” stretch as I’ve experienced in memory, where my brain and I were desperately shouting “SAVE US!” (46A).

A Capital-P Puzzle.  The kind that keeps my head small, that keeps me from being jaded about crosswords.  And I’m grateful for that!

I loved [What a king might sit on?] for SLATS, which brought a huge “Hah!”.  I loved [What banana bread is often baked in] because I haven’t thought about banana bread in ages, and what a divine flavor it has!  

I also loved uncovering BOX BRAIDS and it not helping me figure out how the theme was supposed to work because I was so stubbornly set on the wrong direction I started out in.  There’s something very funny in that, in how blind we can make ourselves!

So, much joy, with a heaping side of humility – and I loved it!  Thank you, Adam!

Wow!! This week is funny. Set a PB for both Monday and today and probably my worst time ever for Tuesday! 

What a blast this puzzle was. Took me a hot minute to realise what was going on, but once it clicked boy was it fun! Thanks y’all.  This extends my streak to a new longest record also!

I enjoyed it. I got the trick rather quickly, but I was stuck for a while with TIN CUPS rather than the correct TIN CANS.

Also, this forced me to clarify to myself that FORGO means "not indulge in," while FOREGO (almost always see in the past participle, in the fixed phrase "foregone conclusion") means "predetermine"...though the latter spelling is becoming acceptable for the former meaning (alas, IMHO).

I suspected a trick when FORRENT and TEEMING didn’t work with MOVEON, then the crossing of FORBIDS and TOESHOE gave it away.

BOXBRAIDS was the very last word I found, not knowing either the hairstyle or the movie.
Help. For 20 across, what is the connection of the phrase “aptly” and the answer “MRT?”

As someone who filled in the Down entries first, this puzzle didn't quite work the way it was intended. DEGREES and FORBIDS and then FORRENT and TEEMING weren't hard clues for me to fill in right away... and then it jumbled the across answers. So I completed the entire puzzle with jumbled across answers on the assumption that was the trick.

I understand the grid now, but this one wasn't quite my cup of tea.

Doggone it... I didn't notice that the braiding applied to both of the adjacent words, only the one in the darkened squares. Even when I got down to the last few letters! OK, I started this at 5:15am, but still...
Awesome Thursday! 8 min slower than my average but an absolute banger. Loved it.
28 across: I believe is a unit of  weight, not mass.

I always wonder about the threshold between straight clues and "?" clues.  Sometimes "?" clues encourage lateral thinking. Sometimes they're red herring for speedy solvers.  Maybe LASERSHOW and DIMES would have been too easy to find without the fish.

So, if you FERMENT FIR CONEs, can you use that to paint FRESCOS of BLUE HENs with TOE RINGs?
And do TONGANS have the amenity of DOG BEDS on their FERRIES?

This puzzle's BOX BRAIDS were seriously clever, but . . . meh. Doesn't seem like there's any reason to be braiding those words. TEEMING with FOREGONE humour, perhaps.
Just didn't hit my funny bone.

All's fair in love and Thursdays.

I knew something Thursday-ish was lurking almost immediately when 9D and 10D wouldn't cooperate, so I forged ahead.

My approach to a tricky Thursday is to fill in as many "gimmes" as possible.  This led to 32A, which I didn't know as a gimme but could infer from the crosses.

Once I had BOXBRAIDS , I returned to the problem areas, immediately saw the braiding of the shading, and Voila!  Happy music.

Excellent and challenging puzzle, Adam.

Deb, thanks for sharing that amazing video.  I am in awe of her ability to create such a beautiful hairstyle with 1 in almond shaped nails, and even more that she said "and it only took me about 3 hours"!

Surprised at some of the negativity here, I thought this was on the straightforward side for a Thursday. My 2 cents: I thought the fill was pretty good. I think the constructor gets major style points (if not solving points) for coming up with interlaceable words that make other words (Python or not) and anyone complaining about the new words not being related is smoking something—how many words do you think you could do this with? On the other hand, the braids don’t add much to the solving experience, once you get the trick, which is pretty quickly once you get enough acrosses. So for me this solved more like a Wednesday than a Thursday and the braided answers became more of a confirmation rather than the focus. But still enjoyable and impressive.

I thought IPAS were hop-ular brews.

...

I'll see myself out.

Oh, God.  I know it's going to be BRAIDS of some sort.  I know precious little about Janet Jackson, much less what hairstyle she wore in some movie I never saw, but I just know it's going to be BRAIDS of some sort.  Those gray squares are just screaming BRAIDS at me.

And what I know is that I don't want to BRAID anything in this puzzle.  Truly I don't.

I just about never do this, but I skip the entire NW and jump right to the revealer section.   it could be a TWIST of some sort too.

I don't want to TWIST anything either.

Nope, it's BRAIDS.  Just like I feared.  What kind of BRAIDS?  I have no idea, but it won't really make any difference, will it?

Lots of pop culture, it seems, in this puzzle.  It's hard enough for me to cope with pop culture when I don't have to BRAID it.  I could look up the answers and then BRAID them, but somehow I just don't want to.  This feels too much like work to me.

Instead of braiding, I'm bailing.  That's absolutely no reflection on the puzzle.  It's a reflection on me.  I'm pretty lazy and extremely hedonistic and this just seems like more trouble than it's worth.

Before I look at the Answer Key, I just want to say..."No fair!" 

 The ABC "Bachelor" (Srsly?) and 'king sitting on...SLATS? SLABS? SLAMS?.... SLAWS?  .....followed by the ?Dutch? 'Muse' for Picasso with the Craps term and a hairstyle  (wow, Natick much?) 
But at least with this one I had a chance of a good guess....

Okay.  That said, I really liked the trick and the AHA! Moment....and OMG the woven letters making some charming/entertaining words or phrases....   and most of all the little delight in the hint of "yon bonny BANKS and yon bonny BRAEs".....like the drop of nectar taken from a single honeysuckle bloom.
The braids were easy and fun  to solve, but I got hung up on some of the more obscure words, like IOS

Good morning! Caught on pretty fast to the "braided entries", and they were clever, although I considered them more twisted or checkerboarded than braided. The braiding video was really cool - thanks for sharing it. 
Now an actual 3 strand braid of words that worked the same way? That would be tough.

If the puzzle can be solved in two ways it should be completable as both ways. I figured if I had the down answers filled consistently and correctly then it would do a cute little animation of the braiding when I was finished.

I really did not expect to get the music when I first filled in the puzzle because some areas felt "naticky", but I did.  My time was even 12% below average.

I am happy with the trick I was given.  Although I had briefly considered the possibility that the down answers to the braids might have some further meaning, I am sure it was challenge enough just to end up with recognizable words, so I am in the camp of that would be asking too much.
Really enjoyed this puzzle! Thanks Adam!
This was a bit tricky to do online, as the shaded squares disappear when the clue is highlighted.  Arggggh.
Hated this puzzle!

I liked the theme, and nice to see the unbraided entries actually spelled words (this puzzle wouldn't have been possible if the constructor attempted to tie them to the theme). Only nit was abuela crossing biota & Dora - had to guess on that.

I really enjoyed this, but it turned out I braided the answers the wrong way! The real pleasant surprise here was how quickly the braiding mechanic became apparent. I think the surrounding fill was easy enough that, with so many letters, the trick was apparent. It was very well done!

I misunderstood the trick and entered all the downs as coherent words which merely flipped two letters in every other across going down the braids. 

Didn’t get the happy music so took another look. Realized both downs were braiding with each other. Should have realized sooner. Oh well. Got there. 

If the goal of the shading was to help us see the pattern, perhaps two shades should have been used. With only one shaded it appears only one word is braiding. 

Really appreciated the cleverness of the constructor though. Not complaining.

What a fun puzzle! I had to check Deb's column because I didn't know what kind of braids they were, but I was able to do the rest of the puzzle knowing the gray boxes indicated braided answers. I love the 2nd set of words being unrelated to the clued ones. Go Blue Hens!
Love this theme! Best tricky Thursday puzzle in a while.  Kudos!

Always happy to see a DC superhero reference in the puzzle. If you liked the answer to 27 Down, then I urge you to listen to this short parting message from Michael Keaton delivered at a commencement ceremony in Ohio 6 or 7 years ago: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KAVvny-FxjA

Wow!
Just Wow
What a rollercoaster of a solve!


Can we go again?
Very nice!
Well, its certainly cutesy. And that seems to really please those who certainly like cutesy. Isn't that cute?

This was a great puzzle! It took me a lot of crossings to complete enough zigzags for the penny to drop.
Interesting [to me, anyway] was the fact that the "X" in BOXBRAIDS was my final letter, and thus the day's "Revealer" functioned as a "Obscurer."

Kudos to Ms. Amien and the editors this time for compiling what I think is the most-highly-illustrated explanatory column I've ever seen. 

Wagner's reference to his appreciation for the power of PYTHON makes me worry about his next offering. HOW ABOUT THIS: A "Double Helix" theme where one "strand reads top-to-bottom  as here, but the complementary strand is "anti-parallel" --as in real DNA... and thus reads bottom-to-top.

Can I get back to work now, please? :-)

I figured out we had to twist the words early on and my heart dropped because I have a tough time parsing downs longer than 5 (visually) but I persevered and got it done!

One time I had box braids and went to the library and all the little kids thought I was actress/singer Brandy lol.

I did what some others did, filled in the down answers straight, and conceded a flipped letter in every other across answer. No music. I then braided them, still to no avail. Turns out the “twos column” being the nOES was the wrong line of thinking. After finally realizing the intended meaning of row and braiding the theme clues again, success was achieved. Thanks for a nice challenge!

I’m in the camp that chose to fill in a way that made the vertical entries make sense, which made some of the horizontal clues into gibberish (but it’s a Thursday, so gibberish didn’t faze me). 

Now that I see it completed, I get that this way is cleaner. But also, as someone who has spent many hours braiding hair, my focus was also on what was happening on the horizontal plane (ie switching off from hand to hand). I wonder if that’s why my brain went there first. 

It would have been neat if both ways of “braiding” had been accepted, similar to how multiple rebus entries can be considered correct.

Really enjoyed this one! Looking at the various controversies in the comments today, I have a few thoughts: 1) Often (usually?) grey squares will guide a fill--that is, tracing an answer along the gray squares will reveal where the letters go according to whatever "trick" is happening. Think of embedded answers, for instance. 2) I enjoyed this even though I completely missed that the downs *as filled* were also coherent answers. When Deb's column called that out, my enjoyment turned to admiration. I don't feel like I have to be smarter than the constructor in order to be satisfied; in fact, I like it when I can marvel at the constructor's cleverness. I want to be smart enough to solve it (and, having been at this for almost five decades, I usually am); thankfully I can still take joy in the skills of others (Python or no).
I thoroughly enjoyed figuring this one out.
Got the theme pretty quickly. Nice puzzle Adam.

Clever theme.  We got the switching letters pretty quickly. And noticed the acrosses could be correct and the downs could be correct, but not a the same time.  Hmmm.  But we did like “Academic achievements” to be DOGBEDS.  

So we decided made all the downs correct (i.e., match the clues). No music, but we did notice the grey squares twisted back and forth to made real words, but saw no theme there.  

Using crosses, we guessed the correct revealer was BOXBRAIDS, but weren’t sure. We knew the movie, and how JJ looked, but did not know the name of her hairstyle.  So we learned that (Yay!). But still couldn’t see what the trick was.  

Bumbling on, we made the crosses correct (i.e., match the clues), leaving the downs incorrect, but showing real words.  Cue the happy music!   But what the heck was the trick?

Oh, the correct down answers twisted down.  Like….oh [expletive deleted], like BRAIDS!   We initially felt really dumb, but then smiled and laughed at how clever this puzzle was.  

A classic gotcha.  Well done!

I enjoyed this!  I appreciated the shaded squares, especially when I figured that Janet was probably wearing braids of some kind.  Took me a while to figure out what kind, especially since I had BIOme instead of BIOTA, and don't know craps or Picasso's muse.
Also had app instead of PDF for too long - but still finished under my Thursday average.  Love Thursdays, thanks for a fun one!

Wabbits, wabbits, wabbits!

ANNIE'S? Oh, right, the organic crackers...which are shaped like cute little bunnies. I've never eaten them, but I had seen them on the shelves of the A to Z warehouse. Big BRAIDS made sense, because I at least remembered that Janet's were long. Never knew of the BOX variety, but the TRIX rabbit saved me in the end.

Whoof, I had to laugh when I saw folks were saying this one was too easy, because it really got me for whatever reason. I got the general idea of the theme, but I went so far off track thinking it involved actually swapping some of the letter positions, that I had to resort to the check button to push me back in the right direction. Between that and the larger-than-average number of terms and names that I wouldn't be able to guess on my own, I guess this just wasn't the Thursday for me. Maybe things will get back on track with just "normal" difficult Friday and Saturday puzzles!

"You want me to bet on your hairstyling abilities?"
"It's a lock!"

(Sounds like a tress exercise.)
I’m very confused about BLUEHEN

Why is “FORBIDS” given as the answer in the theme explanation when it solves to “FORGONE” instead? 
And braids are in threes anyway, not twos. Two is just a twist.

as someone who’s hair is currently in BOXBRAIDS to avoid getting up extra early to do it before my 830s, I adored this puzzle! I actually managed to figure out a Thursday theme!!!! (well ~kinda~ bc I “unbraided” the entries on the downs, THEN noticed the acrosses were weird and had to go back.) but that didn’t stop me from hyping myself up because I made halfway before even opening the wordplay!!!! I even managed to avoid ye olde ECG vs EKG debacle! 🤩 my recent obsession with crosswording to get through a boring lecture is paying off (don’t worry, my grades are great as well 😌)

still had a few look-ups— one day I’ll learn every achievement of Mr T and these various celebs of before my time but for now I gotta go to class.

do the emus like ANNIES? I heard their cheddar bunnies are yummy, might pick some up for a snack after class 🐰
What amazes me, is not just the braiding of the answers, but that the remaining straight downs are not just gibberish but real words. What a treat.
Enjoyed it thoroughly! When I sussed the theme, I had a little chairdance. I found it a very satisfying solve perfect for a Thursday.
I really enjoyed this puzzle! I "braided" the across answers, leaving the down answers readable in a straight line. My only critique is that the puzzle should have been solvable either way.
“Solved” this puzzle in 36 min except that I left the down answers readable rather than the across, so I didn’t get the credit :( Should be correct both ways!
Whew, that was a bit perplexing until I saw the creativeness of the puzzle. I'm on a mission to complete every puzzle this year ... on track thus far!
Loved this one! Just challenging enough to still be fun.
Didn't read all the comments. Maybe others have already noted that there are actually two solutions to this puzzle depending on how you fill the braid.

I guess I'm the only one who didn't like the puzzle, and I usually love the ones with a "trick". Just didn't work for me today. 
:(

Boy, there's some really deep misunderstanding about the coding language Python there, either on my part of other's part.

Python isn't just some new magic AI device that creates software, I don't think.  

Unless something enormous has happened to Python in the last few years, It's just a programming language (and an oldish one at that).  It might be used to try a lot of different combinations quickly.

It's not something the constructor just plugged into, got a puzzle, didn't even both to read it, and sent it off to the Times.
In French they would say that this puzzle was "un enculage de mouches".

I'm a mid tier solver here, and I figured out the braided answers after 20 minutes or so.

But biota, bets, and Dora together threw me for a loop. Biome was the best I could do. And not having heard of box braids added to my pain. 

So this was clearly unfair, unjust, and probably some sort of deep state cultural misappropriation. 

I demand a prorated refund of my subscription. Or a package of Oreos.
The answer key is not loading and I could use the help!
I call BS
Brilliant! I love this puzzle! I didn’t pick up the theme until I'd filled both NE and NW with crosses, and if I hadn't got the theme I never would have filled that nasty SW quadrant.
Absolutely loved this puzzle! I picked it up right away but it was still tricky to make my brain think in zig-zags rather than straight down. Very fun to complete.
Congratulations, Adam. Such a fun fill. Have to admit I spent too long wondering if there were more to 38A. Loved the twists.

A puzzle that is fun and challenging to construct is not necessarily one that is fun or challenging to solve (I almost said "play" but I wouldn't want to offend anybody here). I sometimes wonder if the editorial team here thinks their audience is primarily other crossword constructors.

Impressive feat of construction, and the shading along with the center revealer made the gimmick apparent quickly enough.  I enjoyed it, but knew as I was solving that it would lead to some gripes.  Oh well.  Thursdays aren’t for everyone but it’s the day I always look forward to the most and this was a great one!

Interesting puzzle and theme, if a bit too easy for a Thursday. 

I am puzzled by all the people who seemed set on entering the words without the weaving. 

Do you not pay attention to the crosses? Or, did you think, as I did, that it was too easy a theme, and were hoping (as I did) that the theme was tricker than it actually was? And that nonsensical crosses you saw would somehow make sense, once the theme was revealed? 


Hardroch: I tried to share an article from the PPH about some Harpswell local news the other day, but I guess the emus don't like messages like that. Sorry!

I have to side with the "too far by a mile" crowd here.  Yes, there are tricks and rebuses but I have a problem with being forced to enter totally incorrect words to complete the puzzle.  I saw early that substitution was going to be required, but for instance, the "correct" answer being dogbed went against my every thought of what a crossword is, was, and should be.  To avoid the snark from the resident caped defender, I'll just say that this was beyond my skill level when actually it caused me to break all the rules I've learned over the years.
I did not find this one to be enjoyable at all. Thursday is usually my favorite day.  The braiding concept was a bit of a stretch (IMO).

The braiding was incredibly cool!  It took me a long time to get it, and I had to use your article for help, but once I caught on it was fun. In fact, I wish it had been possible to have had more of them.  

There were a handful of others that completely stumped me. For example, I had no idea who Bruce Wayne is. But I'm also the only person in America who doesn't really enjoy the Marvel movies (of course, their being 17 hours long doesn't help).

I actually knew the one about Picasso because not one but *two* of my sisters-in-law are art historians!  How cool is that?

Anyway, peace be with you guys.

I’m guessing that out there somewhere right now is a dedicated cruciverbailst, heroically crafting a set of eight clues that could each serve for a pair of both the “straight” and the woven words simultaneously. (See attempts toward this idea by others, way below.) This prediction is not to steal your hypothetical thunder, for it will be much-deserved.

Rather, this is just to say that, like the editor(s) who will have to go through all these comments, you have a full plait of work ahead of you.

It didn't take too long to figure out the "braided" answers, but it was somewhat perplexing when first trying. Noticed the shaded squares, and finally decided to twist the answers to follow the patterns, which worked, and helped out on a couple answers. Didn't take long to figure out BOX BRAIDS when I got there, despite having daughters who rarely wore braids.

I got the draft animal a bit differently—when directing farm animals pulling implements, the typical directions given were "gee" to turn right or "haw" to turn left. The three letter answer space led to the correct option.

Fun puzzle, Adam, and thanks!
But what are “Tongans”? Residents of the Polynesian island of Tonga? Seems like a stretch.
I had a really rough time mentally rearranging the letters after I figured out the theme, but I'm happy Mr. T made it to the crossword two days in a row!

Step back three inches or three feet when you see a grid for the first time. Ask it questions. Try to see what is there to see.
I’m not addressing all the proud failures today but the puzzled solvers. Step back and investigate the grid as it is presented before jumping into unknown waters.

The first impression for the patient solver should have been:
the downs; the key is in the downs.

Let me offer: when you suspect the trick is in the downs (which should have been extremely obvious today), solve the acrosses as best you can and let those fills inform your idea of the downs.

When a cross reference is ever offered, there is a rule:
See N down + With X, …
always always always means the “see N down” fill follows the “with X” fill -
 you either get that or … not. Don’t keep blaming the editors, please. They work hard at this.

All the horrible negativity here translating to
“I didn’t get it so it was terrible
and
anybody who did get it is a smarmy jerk”
is enough to just wish
“Rex Parker Trashes the NYT Crossword” was a steady link here, available to all,
so all the haters could just get on along to their true and honest home.

The trick was made clear, the editing was consistent, bravo to the constructor, and thanks to the editors and columnist.
Yep, same. Broke my streak because I couldn't figure out what I missed, and I had just gotten it exactly backwards. 😕

It seems to me that the Thursday tricks have many times resulted in the true answer not being in the corresponding squares, but it somehow uses them, and the corresponding squares have a word or words that are not responsive to the corresponding clue. 

Egad, did I explain that right?

And maybe this was mentioned already. Too many comments to do an exhaustive search...

Once again, the online puzzle had no shaded squares, at least on my computer. This has been consistently happening for several weeks now. And yes, i can imagine that they would have made this puzzle a lot easier to solve!
Wonderful puzzle! A pleasure to solve!
Overly clever. Too cheeky. Go back to rebuses, please!
Finding answers that fulfilled all of the requirements must have been a real brain-buster for the constructor. What a twisty puzzle. I liked it so much I had to try and explain it to my wife.

Wow great puzzle! And good long column by Deb explaining it! I was getting the hang of it but had to go and reorder my letters in the northwest after seeing Deb’s explanation, for which thank you. Am going to save this as a Puzzle of the Year for Thursday.

Like some others, apparently, I outsmarted myself by catching the trick early on and "braiding" too early, e.g., TeoSHOE, MOevON, etc.  IMO, the editors could've provided some more guidance.

Otherwise a very clever puzzle.

⭐️⭐️⭐️

@Some guy 

The theme was BOX BRAIDS, as stated in 32A.  Each pair of down answers where there are gray squares are braided.

In addition to the correct answers formed by the "braided" words, the two straight-down words that make up the pair, suce as DOGBEDS and FERRIES at 2D and 3D, are also actual words, although not sensible answers to the clues.

That, my friend, was the theme.

@Robert Ljungquist from wiki:
The tonne is a unit of mass equal to 1,000 kilograms.

@Robert Ljungquist 
I’m glad you brought this subject up, as we went through a similar discussion a couple of months ago. On 3/11/2024 the clue for 1A was “British weight unit” with the answer GRAM. This caused quite a stir with over 20 comments. One side seemed to think the editors totally messed up as this is a unit of mass (many on this side perhaps suffered from Steve L’s TCS). The other side felt that in common usage we often order weights at the butcher shop, or bathroom scale weights, in kilograms. TONNES has appeared about 30 times or so, and almost half the time it has been clued as some kind of British “weight”. As Jo from DC correctly points out, TONNE is an equivalent of “metric ton” which in reality is a mass unit. The term on this side of the pond (“short or long ton”) usually (but not always) refers to a “weight”, while the avoir du pois  mass unit is a “slug”. ( I remember when someone in the March puzzle comments lamented the absence of “banana-grams” in it, I pointed out the U.S. version of that is the “banana slug”).

@Josh 

It took me forever to finally realize DIMES were physically smaller, thus making it the right answer.  All I could think was that they were worth 10 whole cents, and two nickels.

When I was a kid finding a dime was like discovering gold.

@festy 

I am certainly not the caped defender, but I would say this.

I may have, in the past, been critical and maybe even just the tiniest bit, snarky (microscopically, of course) in my replies to people not liking the puzzle.

I'll say this for the record--I've modified my stance to "you can dislike the puzzle all you like, but please don't just call it 'stupid' or 'crap'".

That sort of criticism is destructive, and I try to remember that the people who do these puzzles are putting their heart and soul into them, I would imagine.  Because the pay can't possibly match the effort.

Anyway, my two cents.

The BLUE HEN is the state bird of Delaware, and the athletic teams from the University of Delaware are the Fightin' BLUE HENs, named for the cockfighting birds that the Revolutionary War soldiers from this state carried as mascots. Famous BLUE HENs include Joe Flacco and Elena Della Donne.

@Robert Ljungquist You are technically correct as some dictionaries say "a unit of weight equal to 1000 kilograms" when they should say "...equal to that of...". As I'm sure you know, it is common to confuse weight and mass because of the association due to the effect of gravity on mass. For a given mass its weight will depend upon the strength of the gravitational field acting upon it. So, the weight of an object can vary from place to place, even on Earth.
